title: California Post poaches Ben Bolch as Los Angeles Times sports staff dwindles to nine full-time staff writers
description: LOS ANGELES ‚Äî The California Post has hired veteran sportswriter Ben Bolch from the Los Angeles Times, marking the third departure from the Times‚Äô sports section to the New York Post‚Äìbacked West Coast startup as it ramps up staffing ahead of its official launch later this month.
fullText:
LOS ANGELES ‚Äî The California Post has hired veteran sportswriter Ben Bolch from the Los Angeles Times, marking the third departure from the Times‚Äô sports section to the New York Post‚Äìbacked West Coast startup as it ramps up staffing ahead of its official launch later this month.

PERSONAL NEWS: After 26 years at the Los Angeles Times, I am joining the new sports team at @capostsports under the direction of @Ryan_Kostecka as a senior college sports reporter. My first day is Jan. 20. We are building something special and I hope you'll join us.

‚Äî Ben Bolch (@latbbolch) January 12, 2026

It was one of several moves the California Post sports staff made on Monday.

Vincent Bonsignore, who had covered the Las Vegas Raiders the previous six years for the Las Vegas Review-Journal and had spent nearly two decades covering Los Angeles sports for the Southern California News Group, joined the Post as a senior NFL columnist.

Career news: After 6 amazing years covering the @Raiders for the Review-Journal, I am joining the new sports team at @capostsports under the leadership of @Ryan_Kostecka as a senior NFL columnist. I start next week. I am beyond excited to begin my new journey with the incredible‚Ä¶

‚Äî Vincent Bonsignore (@VinnyBonsignore) January 12, 2026

Michael Durate, who has covered Los Angeles sports for the past 12 years for NBC Los Angeles, joined as a senior sports writer.

BREAKING NEWS: After 12 amazing years at NBC, I‚Äôm excited to announce that I will be joining the All-Star team being assembled by @Ryan_Kostecka as a senior sports reporter with the California Post¬†@californiapost.
I would never have such opportunities without all of you who‚Ä¶

‚Äî Michael J. Duarte (@michaeljduarte) January 12, 2026

Charly Hill, who graduated from Miami in 2024 and has interned and freelanced at Bleacher Report, TNT Sports and NBC, joined as a sports content creator.

I‚Äôm not typically active on Twitter, but that‚Äôs all about to change with my new role at the California Post as a Sports Content Creator

So excited to be a part of what‚Äôs shaping up to be an incredible year for California sports! pic.twitter.com/EOieGODH0b

‚Äî charly d (@charlydyannhill) January 8, 2026

Bolch, who has covered UCLA athletics for the Los Angeles Times for more than a decade and spent 26 years at the paper overall, becomes the latest high-profile addition for the California Post, which has aggressively targeted established Southern California journalists to anchor its coverage.

His move follows the recent exits of former Los Angeles Times sports columnist Dylan Hernandez and Dodgers beat writer Jack Harris, who ¬†announced last month they were joining the California Post.

With Bolch‚Äôs departure, the Los Angeles Times is now left with just nine full-time sports staff writers, a stark contraction for a paper that once boasted one of the deepest sports departments in the country.

Outside of the editors, the Los Angeles Times sports staff is currently led by columnist Bill Plaschke, senior writers Bill Shaikin and Kevin Baxter, Thuc Nhi Nguyen and Broderick Turner on the Lakers, Ryan Kartje on USC, Gary Klein on the Rams, Sam Farmer on the Chargers and Eric Sondheimer on high schools.

The Los Angeles Times was slated to have the second-largest contingent of sports staffers covering the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo behind NBC, which is the broadcast home of the Olympics, before the pandemic. The plan at the time, according to sources, was to send 14 reporters and photographers to Tokyo to produce a separate daily color section, as it first did in 1984 when the games were held in Los Angeles. The Times will be covering next month‚Äôs Winter Games in Italy with one writer as Thuc Nhi Nguyen will be taking a break from the Lakers beat to cover the games in Milan and Cortina d'Ampezzo.

When Patrick Soon-Shiong purchased the Los Angeles Times in 2018, he told The Washington Post, ‚ÄúOne of our priorities is to be the sports paper of the nation.‚Äù Since the pandemic in 2020, however, the sports section has been reduced to the final four or five pages of the California section five days a week, with a standalone sports section of six to eight pages appearing only twice per week.

Despite its statewide branding, the California Post's initial sports coverage will be centered squarely on Los Angeles, with a primary emphasis on the sports and teams the Los Angeles Times still covers in the Dodgers, Lakers, Rams, Chargers, USC and UCLA.

Hernandez and Harris will lead its MLB and Dodgers coverage, while Southern California News Group Lakers beat writer Khobi Price and longtime Lakers reporter Melissa Rohlin, who joined the Post last week, will anchor its NBA and Lakers coverage. Bonsignore will lead the NFL and Rams coverage while Bolch will lead college sports coverage, focusing on USC and UCLA.

The staffing losses at the Los Angeles Times come amid continued upheaval at the paper, which has faced newsroom cuts, buyouts and mounting uncertainty about its long-term investment in daily sports coverage.

Meanwhile, the California Post is not done hiring. Sources familiar with the startup‚Äôs plans say the outlet is continuing to pursue additional Times sports writers and other well-known local journalists before its launch on Jan. 26.

title: Man United‚Äôs biggest winners and losers after Ruben Amorim is sacked
description: Manchester United are set to announce Michael Carrick as caretaker manager until the end of the season after the shock decision to sack Ruben Amorim last week.Under-18s coach Darren Fletcher took char...
fullText:
Manchester United are set to announce Michael Carrick as caretaker manager until the end of the season after the shock decision to sack Ruben Amorim last week.

Under-18s coach Darren Fletcher took charge of the senior side in Amorim‚Äôs absence, leading United to a draw with Burnley in the Premier League and a defeat in the FA Cup third round against Brighton & Hove Albion.

There were even suggestions the Scot was under consideration to take the role permanently, but these unimpressive results ruled him out of the running.

Initially, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer was the frontrunner for the role, with sporting director Jason Wilcox preferring the Norwegian to Carrick.

However, a ‚Äústrong interview‚Äù from the 44-year-old coach, who previously managed Middlesbrough for nearly three years, led United‚Äôs hierarchy to pivot towards him.

Sir Alex Ferguson is even understood to have given his approval to Carrick taking the helm at Old Trafford over Solskjaer.

The former midfielder will be officially announced tomorrow, with the small matter of the Manchester Derby this weekend to contend with as his first hurdle in the job.

Carrick is expected to implement a fluid 4-2-3-1 system, a shift away from the 3-4-2-1 his predecessor was inexorably wed to and the sword upon which he ultimately fell. However, the transition of powers goes far beyond the formation on the pitch.

The dismissal of the Portuguese coach wipes the slate clean for a host of players, both inside and outside of Old Trafford. It also brings jeopardy to some who were closely allied with him, with their role in the team ‚Äì and their future at the club ‚Äì now under serious doubt.

The Peoples Person has analysed the workforce, including those on temporary leave, at United to assess which employees are the biggest winners and, conversely, the biggest losers from the boss‚Äôs sacking.

Let‚Äôs dive in ‚Äì starting with those who will have been celebrating the P45 notice last week.

Mainoo will be the biggest beneficiary of Amorim‚Äôs departure, as it would have been the midfielder leaving Old Trafford if the coach had remained. He was a poor fit in the 3-4-2-1 system, lacking the physicality to play in midfield and the attacking threat to be a forward. A shift to a three-man midfield, be it a 4-2-3-1 or 4-3-3, should see the 20-year-old technician re-establish himself as the future of the football club.

Yoro is another youngster set to benefit from Amorim‚Äôs dismissal, but the 20-year-old defender did not fall foul of his head coach in the way Mainoo did; rather, the French starlet was rated by Amorim but simply struggled to adapt to the demands his system placed on the outside centre-backs. Yoro established himself as the best defensive prospect in a back four with LOSC Lille. For the first time since arriving at Old Trafford, he will get the chance to play in this familiar setting under Carrick.

Despite Fernandes being Amorim‚Äôs right-hand man, the Portuguese talisman will be unleashed in Carrick‚Äôs system, as he will return to his rightful No. 10 role. The 31-year-old has spent this season deployed deeper in a midfield pivot, playing closer to his own goal than the opposition‚Äôs, yet still has the most assists in the Premier League. Just imagine how many he‚Äôll have if played further forward.

Perhaps the most contentious choice on the list, but Rashford‚Äôs path to an unlikely Old Trafford return is much¬†clearer without a Portuguese obstacle in his way. The 28-year-old forward has been red hot since joining Barcelona on loan. And while the Spanish giants want to keep him in Catalonia, their financial situation makes a permanent deal difficult. United are expected to look for a dynamic left winger this summer; Amorim‚Äôs dismissal means they already have one on their books.

Casemiro had fought his way back into the fold at Old Trafford under Amorim, despite the ‚Äúfootball having left him‚Äù in a horrifying campaign before the Portuguese tactician arrived. It had appeared a foregone conclusion that the 33-year-old Brazilian, who turns 34 next month, would leave United this summer, as his exorbitant contract is set to expire. But there was talk of a renewal, on reduced wages, given how important Amorim considered the defensive midfielder‚Äîwhich is why he is the biggest loser from Amorim‚Äôs exit, because he will now be following his head coach through the door.

Jack of all trades, master of none. Never has a statement applied more aptly to a footballer than Diogo Dalot, who is capable of playing as a full-back, wing-back, or winger, on both sides of the pitch, with equal ineffectiveness. There is a strong sense Dalot‚Äôs standing in the United dressing room ‚Äì he is part of the leadership group ‚Äì had more to do with him sharing his head coach‚Äôs mother tongue than anything he could do with a ball at his feet. When Noussair Mazraoui is back from the Africa Cup of Nations, Dalot should resume his rightful place on the bench.

Mount had found a home at Old Trafford under Amorim, after 15 months spent looking like a nomad after arriving from Chelsea. The 3-4-2-1 system was one the English midfielder had thrived in previously, and his best performances in a red shirt were delivered in it. Mount remains a great squad player, with excellent versatility, but a return to a 4-2-3-1 with flying wingers puts him in direct competition with Fernandes ‚Äì a fight with only one winner, meaning there has to be a loser.

Wait, what? Wasn‚Äôt Bruno one of the biggest winners? Let me explain. Fernandes‚Äô best position is as an attacking midfielder with the freedom to drift where he wants, as he will under Carrick. But the biggest proponent for United‚Äôs captain remaining United‚Äôs captain ‚Äì given how close he came to leaving last summer amid eye-watering offers from Saudi Arabia ‚Äì was Amorim. INEOS were, inexplicably, ambivalent whether Fernandes stayed or went ‚Äì and if another bid arrives from the Middle East this summer, they will not have a fiery Portuguese coach demanding it is rejected. The most unfortunate part of Amorim‚Äôs exit is it increases the probability his compatriot on the pitch will also leave ‚Äì and this would make the United fanbase the real losers.

There are strong arguments for even more players being affected, positively or negatively, by INEOS‚Äôs decision to bring an end to Amorim‚Äôs tumultuous tenure. Matheus Cunha is one, while the pair of right wingers ‚Äì Amad and Bryan Mbeumo ‚Äì are likely to now play in a system with only one right winger.

But, undoubtedly, the biggest loser in the debacle which has engulfed Old Trafford over the past week is Sir Jim Ratcliffe.

INEOS have been nothing short of a disaster since the British billionaire became United‚Äôs co-owner in 2024, with a long¬†list of inexplicable decisions, on and off the pitch, that have worsened the state of the club, not improved it. A fish rots from the head ‚Äì and a foul stench is emanating from the Theatre of Dreams at the moment.

Featured image Carl Recine via Getty Images

The Peoples Person has been one of the world‚Äôs leading Man United news sites for over a decade. bsky.social

title: Robert Lewandowski refuses to fade quietly at Barcelona
description: Less playing time, same killer instinct, and a future that keeps everyone guessing
fullText:
Robert Lewandowski no longer needs ninety minutes to leave his mark. At 37, with his contract winding down and his role reshaped under Hansi Flick, the Polish striker keeps doing the one thing that complicates every internal discussion at the club: scoring.

His goal in the Spanish Super Cup final against Real Madrid was just another reminder. The movement between the center backs, the timing of the run, the calm finish over Thibaut Courtois after Pedri‚Äôs pass. It was all classic Lewan-goal-ski.

It was also his fourth goal in a Super Cup final since arriving in 2022, a competition he seems to treat as personal territory. Three Super Cups, two league titles and a Copa del Rey later, he has reached 111 goals in a Barcelona shirt and is now ten away from breaking into the club‚Äôs top ten scorers, all-time.

The only thing that has changed with his advanced age is his place in the rhythm of matches. Flick has been willing to sit him down. Lewandowski has already watched three games this season from the bench without playing a minute and has come on nine times as a substitute. A muscle injury earlier in the campaign forced caution from the boss, but rotation has also been a deliberate choice, especially with Ferran Torres thriving in the same role. But the numbers simply refuse to align with the idea of decline. Ten goals in just over 1,000 minutes. One goal roughly every 100 minutes. Last season was even sharper: 42 goals, one every 93.5 minutes.

Being on the bench often has not slowed him down. He did not play a single minute in the Super Cup semifinal and still started and scored in the final. He came off the bench in the league derby against Espanyol and decided the game in the closing moments. According to Marca, Lewandowski has not challenged Flick over his reduced minutes and has accepted the situation without tension. After lifting the Super Cup, he summed it up simply: ‚Äúwe won the Super Cup as a team.‚Äù

Inside the dressing room, that attitude matters. Flick recently went further, stating, ‚ÄúI have never had a professional like him.‚Äù Scenes in training, from his constant interaction with Pedri and Ferran to his role welcoming Bardghji, point to a player who understands the moment he is in and is not fighting it.

The uncertainty, however, is real. Lewandowski‚Äôs contract expires on June 30 and his salary remains one of the highest in the squad. According to AS, Saudi Arabia is emerging as a serious option if he leaves, driven by both sporting interest and financial power. MLS clubs, including Chicago Fire, have also made inquiries, though their offers fall well short of Saudi figures. Lewandowski himself insists no decision has been taken and that discussions with Flick will be key, repeating that ‚Äúthe future is still open.‚Äù

Lewandowski plays less, but scores faster. He no longer dominates every lineup, but still decides finals. As the season heads toward its decisive stretch, his goals may yet define another title run.

title: Juventus eye move for Man City‚Äôs Bernardo Silva
description: Juventus are eyeing Manchester City ace Bernardo Silva, plotting a move for the diminutive Portuguese starlet this summer (h/t Gianluca DiMarzio).The Bianconeri are understood to be monitoring the Man...
fullText:
Juventus are eyeing Manchester City ace Bernardo Silva, plotting a move for the diminutive Portuguese starlet this summer (h/t Gianluca DiMarzio).

The Bianconeri are understood to be monitoring the Man City midfielder‚Äôs contractual situation as part of a broader strategy to secure elite experience for the next phase of their rebuild.

Silva‚Äôs current deal at the Etihad runs until June 2026, meaning suitors can start speaking to him this winter transfer window, making their case for him to join their club.

No formal approach has been made at this stage, but Juventus view the 30-year-old as a market opportunity worth tracking.

With financial balance remaining central to their planning, the Italian giants are content to wait and assess how Silva‚Äôs situation develops over the coming months.

Despite not posting headline numbers this season, Silva remains a central cog in Pep Guardiola‚Äôs system.

The Portugal international has made 28 appearances across all competitions, scoring once in the Champions League and registering two assists in the Premier League.

However, his value lies less in raw output and 

Silva‚Äôs pedigree is beyond question.

He has won every honour available in English football, boasts 107 international caps, and brings the kind of Champions League know-how Juventus have often prioritised when refreshing their squad.

His versatility, which allows him to operate as a central midfielder, an advanced playmaker, or a wide option, also aligns with Juventus‚Äô desire for multifunctional profiles.

Interest is not limited to Turin. Clubs such as Napoli and Como have also been linked with the Portuguese playmaker. Signing the former AS Monaco man would be a coup.

For now, Juventus are only watching. But if Silva does become available, the Bianconeri intend to be firmly in the conversation.

title: Liverpool target SENSATIONAL Yan Diomande alternative; he's a world-class talent
description: Liverpool are in the fight for Yan Diomande - but they have an alternative. And he's a true world-class talent, too.Yan Diomande is one of the most in-demand talents in world football right now. The I...
fullText:
Liverpool are in the fight for Yan Diomande - but they have an alternative. And he's a true world-class talent, too.

Yan Diomande is one of the most in-demand talents in world football right now. The Ivorian has exploded onto the scene over the last year, first with Leganes and then at RB Leipzig this season.

It's widely expected that he'll move again in 2026, probably for a truly massive fee. Liverpool will likely try to be the team that pays that, according to several outlets.

One of those claiming it is Christian Falk, with the Bayern Munich insider suggesting the Reds are in the race along with most European giants. But there's the problem - the fight to win this race is intense and only one team can win.

Thus it's important that Liverpool have themselves at least one alternative on the wing. They do need to invest in the position, after all, and Diomande can't be their only option.

It seems they do have that alternative, though. And he's a truly world-class talent.

That report by Falk drops an interesting line: Liverpool have Said El Mala on their shortlist, too. Again, they‚Äôre not alone in that but it seems the Koln winger is the consolation prize here.

And what a prize he is. El Mala is still only 19 but has six Bundesliga goals and two assists in a little over 600 minutes this season. It‚Äôs an incredible record, especially as Koln aren‚Äôt playing well.

They‚Äôve won two of their last 14 Bundesliga games. Despite that, El Mala looks like one of the most exciting talents in the league - and one who could compete with Diomande.

Liverpool showed in the summer that they rate Bundesliga talents very highly, spending massively on both Florian Wirtz and Hugo Ekitike. It now seems that they‚Äôll move for another one, be it Diomande or El Mala.

The latter certainly ticks the boxes Liverpool want. He‚Äôs averaging 2.76 successful take-ons per 90 minutes in the Bundesliga this season and the only player in the league averaging more with at least as many minutes is Diomande.

He‚Äôs winning tackles, too, and proving to be a threat in the air. All in all, El Mala is a world-class young talent and one who surely moves up a level in a better team.

title: Lakers player grades: L.A. gets steamrolled by Kings
description: The Lakers defense went from on the mend to very weak on Monday, and it resulted in an unacceptable loss to the Kings.
fullText:
After back-to-back losses to the San Antonio Spurs and Milwaukee Bucks, the Los Angeles Lakers looked to get back in the win column when they faced the struggling Sacramento Kings on Monday. Sacramento had just ended a seven-game losing streak, and it came into this game with a 9-30 record, which was the second-worst record in the Western Conference.

The Lakers got out to an early 19-10 lead thanks to some active defense and several fast-break scores. But they went cold for an extended stretch soon afterward and fell behind by as many as 16 points in the second quarter. An 11-2 Lakers run brought them to within 61-54 at halftime, but Sacramento boosted its lead to 20 minutes later, and the Lakers were never able to mount a serious rally, resulting in a 124-112 loss for them.

Even without three-time All-Star center Domantas Sabonis, who has a meniscus injury, the Kings were able to steamroll L.A. with some precise execution and offense. They shot 58.5% from the field and an unbelievable 65.4% from 3-point range, and they caught Los Angeles slow on its defensive rotations to 3-point shooters. Guard Malik Monk, a former Laker, burned his old team with 26 points and seven treys off the bench. Even Russell Westbrook, another former Laker, hit four of his eight attempts from downtown.

Los Angeles' defense wasn't the only problem. While it shot 48.8% overall, it was just 8-of-36 from beyond the arc and had a pronounced lack of offensive balance. Only four of its players hit double figures in scoring, and only two of its men had more than 13 points.

The Lakers are now on a three-game losing streak, and with a 23-14 record, they're still in fifth place in the Western Conference, but they're in a virtual tie with the sixth-place Phoenix Suns. They're only half a game ahead of the Houston Rockets, who are in seventh place, and they will return home to face the Atlanta Hawks on Tuesday.

Smart had some moments where he played effective defense, but he was a liability on the other end of the court. He missed all five of his shot attempts and scored one point, to go along with two rebounds, two assists and two steals in 31 minutes.

LaRavia was another player who contributed next to nothing offensively. He missed six of his seven shot attempts and went 0-of-5 from 3-point range, and he ended up with two points, two rebounds, three assists and one steal in 31 minutes.

Ayton had nine rebounds in the first half and 13 for the game, including five on the offensive glass, and he went 4-of-7 from the field. While he got eight free throw attempts, which is a high and unusual amount for him, he made just five of them, which limited him to 13 points in 27 minutes. Ayton also contributed one assist and two blocks, but L.A. could've used a little more scoring from him.

James got off to a hot start in this game with several transition buckets and 10 points overall in the first quarter. But he faded afterward and finished with an anemic 22 points on 8-of-17 field-goal shooting while missing all five of his 3-point tries. He also had four rebounds, three assists and one steal in 33 minutes.

Doncic, at times, almost single-handedly prevented L.A. from falling completely out of this contest early on. He had 26 first-half points on 10-of-14 shooting, with 15 of them coming in bunches during the second quarter. He tried to put his team on his back and carry it toward a comeback, but he didn't receive nearly enough help.

In all, he scored 42 points and went 16-of-25 from the field, although he was 2-of-9 from downtown. Doncic also helped out with seven rebounds, eight assists and four steals.

This was a relatively quiet night for Vanderbilt. In 26 minutes, he got four rebounds, but he missed his three field-goal attempts and went scoreless.

Vincent went 3-of-6 overall and 3-of-5 from downtown, giving him nine points, plus one assist and one steal, in 18 minutes. He hit two of his treys early in the fourth quarter to try to jump-start a Lakers comeback, but to no avail.

Hayes was fairly aggressive and energetic throughout this contest. He got 19 minutes of playing time, and he made five of his six shot attempts to finish with 12 points, while also grabbing four offensive rebounds and five total boards.

Knecht got onto the court for 13 minutes and hit two of his six shot attempts, including one 3-pointer. He finished with five points, two rebounds and one assist.

The younger James, Kleber and Smith each played only during the final 1:53 of this game. The younger James hit both of his shot attempts and scored six points, while Kleber and Smith went scoreless.

This article originally appeared on LeBron Wire: Lakers player grades: L.A. gets steamrolled by Kings

title: Mike Tomlin not ready to talk about his future with the Steelers after latest early playoff loss
description: The Texans rolled to an easy 30-6 win over the Steelers in their wild-card matchup on Monday night.
fullText:
Mike Tomlin isn‚Äôt ready to talk about his future with the Pittsburgh Steelers just yet.

And in the immediate aftermath of the team‚Äôs rough 30-6 loss to the Houston Texans in the wild-card round of the playoffs on Monday night, which officially ended their season, it‚Äôs hard to blame the longtime Steelers head coach.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not even in that mindset as I sit here tonight,‚Äù Tomlin said when asked about his future with the team, via Yahoo Sports‚Äô Jori Epstein. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm 

There has been plenty of questions and speculation about Tomlin‚Äôs future in recent weeks as the Steelers had to fight their way into the final playoff spot in the AFC. While Tomlin has accomplished a remarkable amount in his nearly two decades leading the franchise, it‚Äôs easy to understand why.

Tomlin has never had a losing record in his 19 seasons running the Steelers, which marks his only head coaching job in the NFL. He helped them win a Super Bowl during the 2008 campaign, and he‚Äôs been to the playoffs now 13 times.¬†Undoubtedly, he‚Äôll retire as one of the better coaches in the history of the league whenever he chooses to do so.

But recently, especially after longtime quarterback Ben Roethlisberger retired, things have stalled out a bit in Pittsburgh. The organization has not won a playoff game since the 2017 season despite making it in five of the last six seasons.

The fact that some think Tomlin is on the ‚Äúhot seat,‚Äù at least according to quarterback Aaron Rodgers ‚Äî who may have played his last NFL game himself ‚Äî is ridiculous.

Aaron Rodgers, when asked about Mike Tomlin, speaks on Tomlin and on #Packers head coach Matt LaFleur after the @Steelers‚Äô playoff loss: pic.twitter.com/gTNmgQT6Qw

‚Äî Jason Wilde (@jasonjwilde) January 13, 2026

‚ÄúThis league has changed a lot in my 21 years. When you hear conversations about the Mike Tomlin‚Äôs of the world, the Matt LaFleur‚Äôs of the world ‚Ä¶ when I first got in the league there wouldn‚Äôt be conversations about whether those guys were on the hot seat,‚Äù Rodgers said, also referencing the Green Bay Packers head coach.

‚ÄúBut the way the league is covered now and the way that there‚Äôs snap decisions and the validity given to the Twitter experts and all the experts on TV now who make it seem like they know what the hell they‚Äôre talking about, to me that‚Äôs an absolute joke.‚Äù

Tomlin has two years left on his current contract with the Steelers, and there is a team option on his deal for 2027. The Steelers, according to ESPN‚Äôs Adam Schefter, have to decide whether to pick up that option by March 1.

According to Schefter, however, nobody within the organization expects the Steelers to actually fire Tomlin. The Steelers haven‚Äôt fired a head coach since 1968. When Tomlin and the Steelers fired offensive coordinator Matt Canada during the 2023 season, it was the first in-season coordinator change the franchise has had in more than 80 years.¬†The franchise simply doesn‚Äôt make these types of changes.

If that‚Äôs the case, the Steelers will only have a new coach next season if Tomlin opts to walk away from the game himself.¬†And that‚Äôs certainly a possibility.

But any talk about that, Tomlin said, will take place on Tuesday and beyond.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not time for talk,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe agreed we‚Äôll meet tomorrow and go from there. When you‚Äôre in this single elimination tournament, there's not a whole lot to talk about. You win or you go home.‚Äù
